fr.sorbonne_u.utils.aclocks

Class ClocksServer

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sorbonne_u.components.AbstractComponent
      • fr.sorbonne_u.utils.aclocks.ClocksServer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ComponentI

    public class ClocksServer
extends AbstractComponent
    The class ClocksServer implements a component that can be used to share clocks among other components, and more specifically accelerated clocks so that all components can share the same starting Unix epoch time, start instant and acceleration factor.

    Description

    In time-triggered test scenarios, actions performed by components must be synchronised upon a shared view of time. AcceleratedClock provides methods to share access to a common time line, which in fact is two time lines kept synchronised in presence of an acceleration factor. This acceleration factor allows to perform long scenarios in less than actual real time. But having components share the same clock is not so easy. In centralised executions, it would be possible to pass the same AcceleratedClock instance to all components.

    In distributed executions however, it is mandatory to have only one process creating the AcceleratedClock instance. This raises the question about how to get access to this clock for components that reside in other processes. The ClocksServer component provides a solution: create only one clock server accessible to all components an create in it a global clock that will be shared by simply having components retrieving it after its creation.

    Note that in distributed executions, sharing does not mean actually sharing the same AcceleratedClock instance. No simple reference can provide access to the same object from different processes. One solution would have been to have an AcceleratedClock component instead of an object and then having all components accessing this unique component. This solution has one drawback: the latency of RMI calls among processes and across the network. As the AcceleratedClock can easily be copied and copies can be used with the same semantics as sharing a single instance, having copies of the clock within the different processes solves the latency problem. But, indeed, it causes another problem: the synchronisation of the copies. AcceleratedClock use the underlying computer physical clock to evolve the its two time lines. When copies of the same clock execute on different computers, they are no more synchronised than the physical clocks of the two computer are. This is especially important when high acceleration factors are used, as they tend to shorten the actual real time between events and therefore may cause instants inversions among events executed on different computers. A good rule of thumb is to used smaller acceleration factors when executing on several computers and make sure that the computers used for this execution have their clocks synchronised the best possible.

    Mutual exclusion

    As the component is created with only one thread that is systematically used by the inbound port to execute the service calls, they are de facto executed in mutual exclusion. Hence, retrieving a clock with getClock cannot interfere negatively with creating a clock with createClock.

    White-box Invariant

     invariant       true        // no more invariant

    Black-box Invariant

     invariant       true        // no more invariant

    Created on : 2022-11-15

    Author:
    Jacques Malenfant

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      AcceleratedClock createClock(java.lang.String clockURI, long unixEpochStartTimeInNanos, java.time.Instant startInstant, double accelerationFactor)
      create an accelerated clock with the given parameters associated with the given URI.
      AcceleratedClock getClock(java.lang.String clockURI)
      return the clock associated with clockURI of null if none; the result will be serialised and deserialised if the call is made among distributed components, hence creating a copy of the clock local to the receiver process using the physical clock of the receiver host as time base for evolution; the call will block and wait if the clock of the given URI has not been created yet.
      protected void initialise()
      initialise the clock server component.
      void shutdown()
      shutdown the component; inspired from the Java Executor framework.
      void start()
      start the component; this method is automatically called by the component virtual machine after all components have been initialised and the component calls in turn its own inner components.

      • ClocksServer

        protected ClocksServer(java.lang.String clockURI,
                       long unixEpochStartTimeInNanos,
                       java.time.Instant startInstant,
                       double accelerationFactor)
                throws java.lang.Exception
        create the clock server component with an inbound port offering the component interface ClocksServerCI with as URI the value of STANDARD_INBOUNDPORT_URI; the created clock server component will also have a first clock created from the given parameters.

        Contract

         pre     clockURI != null && !clockURI.isEmpty()
 pre     getClock(clockURI) == null
 pre     unixEpochStartTimeInNanos > 0
 pre     startInstant != null
 pre     accelerationFactor > 0.0
 post    getClock(clockURI).getStartEpochNanos() == unixEpochStartTimeInNanos
 post    getClock(clockURI).getStartInstant().equals(startInstant)
 post    getClock(clockURI).getAccelerationFactor() == accelerationFactor
        Parameters:
        clockURI - URI designating the first created clock.
        unixEpochStartTimeInNanos - start time in Unix epoch time expressed in nanoseconds.
        startInstant - start instant to be aligned with the unixEpochStartTimeInNanos.
        accelerationFactor - acceleration factor to be applied between elapsed time as Instant and elapsed time as Unix epoch time in nanoseconds.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - to do.

        public AcceleratedClock createClock(java.lang.String clockURI,
                                    long unixEpochStartTimeInNanos,
                                    java.time.Instant startInstant,
                                    double accelerationFactor)
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        create an accelerated clock with the given parameters associated with the given URI.

        Contract

         pre     clockURI != null && !clockURI.isEmpty()
 pre     unixEpochStartTimeInNanos > 0
 pre     startInstant != null
 pre     accelerationFactor > 0.0
 post    return != null
 post    return.getStartEpochNanos() == unixEpochStartTimeInNanos
 post    return.getStartInstant().equals(startInstant)
 post    return.getAccelerationFactor() == accelerationFactor
 post    getClock(clockURI).equals(return)
        Parameters:

      • getClock

        public AcceleratedClock getClock(java.lang.String clockURI)
                          throws java.lang.Exception
        return the clock associated with clockURI of null if none; the result will be serialised and deserialised if the call is made among distributed components, hence creating a copy of the clock local to the receiver process using the physical clock of the receiver host as time base for evolution; the call will block and wait if the clock of the given URI has not been created yet.

        Contract

         pre     clockURI != null && !clockURI.isEmpty()
 post    true        // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        clockURI - URI of a previously created clock.
        Returns:
        the clock associated with clockURI or null if none.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - to do.
